BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 15, 1915.

THE TIGER SWIMMERS WIN MEET

NOTED LECTURERS COMING HERE

SOPHOMORE BANQUET PEACEFUL

Defeat Hopkins Independents by Score
of 48 to 14 —Win Polo Game
Easily--Nourse Stars.

Dr. John Calvin Ferguson to Lecture on
Chinese Art —Mr. Harrington Emerson to Deliver Series on Efficiency.

Class of 1917 Holds Annual "Feed"
Without the Presence of Freshmen.
Hazing Done Away With.

The Independent swimming team
lost its second meet of the season
last Saturday night, when the
Princeton University squad came
out on top, 48 points to 14. In
the water polo game following the
meet the Tigers were again victorious, scoring six goals to none
for the Black and Blue. Princeton
has held the intercollegiate championship in this branch of sport for
the last five years, so it may be seen
that Hopkins did well to hold their
opponents to only six goals.
Although Hopkins failed to score
a first place, competition was keen
in all the events, the Orange and
Black tankmen having to work especially hard in the fancy diving
and 50-yards dash. In the former
event, -Hoffman, diving for the
Black and Blue, showed wonderful
form and was only beaten out for
first place by a fraction of point.
Frizzell, Princeton's captain, who
won this event, placed second in
last year's intercollegiates, and Berereton, who placed third, finished
in the same position in the championships. In the 50-yards dash,
Woodward and Rowland pushed
the Princeton men hard from start
to finish. In this event the judges
differed as to second place, as
Woodward and Madden finished in
almost a dead heat. The latter was
finally awarded second, with Woodward third. The other events in
which Hopkins showed to advantage were the plunge for distance
and 50-yard back stroke. In both
of these races the Black and Blue
placed second and third, Eiseman
and Getz scoring in the plunge,
while Woodward and Fulton placed
in the back stroke.
Princeton uncovered a varied and
wonderfully strong attack in the
water polo game. Five goals were.
scored in the first half before Hopkins became accustomed to the play
of their more experienced opponents. The second period, however,
showed a much stronger defense
for the Black and Blue, the Tiger
stars being held to one tally. Primrose, H. Woodward and Hoffman
starred for the locals, while Nourse
played althost the entire game for
the Tigers.
Saturday's meet will be the last
for the swimmers, three victories
haying been scored out of five
starts. Swarthmore, City College
and Marston's have been defeated,
while meets have been lost to Navy
and Princeton. Considering the
fact that this is the first year for
the sport at Hopkins, the Black and

Dr. John Calvin Ferguson, who
has for many years devoted his
time to the study of art in China,
will give an illustrated lecture on
"Chinese Art," Monday, March 22,
at 5 P. M., in McCoy Hall. Dr.
Ferguson was president of Nanking
University from 1888 to 1897, and
was president of Nanyang College,
Shanghai, from 1897 to 1902. He
has held many offices of importance
in China, and is a member of a
large number of honorary orders
and learned societies. His work in
China has been extended over many
years, during which time he has
played an important part in the development of many lines of governmental work. He has translated
several important works into the
Chinese tongue.
By virtue of his long and close
acquaintanceship with his subject,
as well as his powers as a lecturer,
his lecture next week promises to
be of an unusually interesting character, and should be especially well
attended.
Beginning with this evening at
8 P. M., Mr. Harrington Emerson,
president of the Emerson Company
of New York, will give a series of
lectures on "Personal and Industrial Efficiency," under the auspices
of the Department of Engineering.
The lectures, which are to be of a
non-technical character, will be open
to all members of the University,
and to the public. The topics are
as follows.
March t5—"The Great Stupidities."
March 22 — "Fundamentals of
Organization."
April I2—"Principles of Efficiency."
April 19—Modern Industry and
Efficiency."
Mr. Emerson, who is an efficiency
engineer of note, gained wide recognition on account of the results
he obtained in his investigation of
the Santa Fe Railroad system.
Since then he has held a position
of high rank among efficiency engineers and has done much to further
the application of the principles of
this rapidly developing science. His
subject is one which should appeal
to everyone, and in view of his
recognized greatness it, is centainly
a privilege of no mean worth to be
able to hear him.

(('ontinued on Page 8, col. 3)

One of the most interesting, original and thoroughly enjoyable banquets ever given by a Hopkins
undergraduate class took place last
Thursday night, when the Class of
1017 gathered about the jovial
board for an evening of feasting
and revelry.
The banquet was held at the
Hotel Rennert, and a large number
of hungry second-year men were on
hand when, at 7.30 o'clock hostilities were formally opened in a
private dining-room. Hopkins precedent was altered in the selection
of toast-master, in that Mr. Joseph
Chesley filled the position which is
customarily reserved for the class
president. Mr. Chesley acquitted
himself very creditably in the performance of his duties, and fully
justified the action of the committee
who requested him to do the honors of the evening.
As is by no means universally the
case, the speeches that followed the
banquet proper proved even more
attractive than had the delights of
French cooking, even though the
latter was disguised on the menu
cards arranged for the occasion
under highly suggestive and reminiscent titles. Eddie Stuart sounded
the - dominantly serious and contemplative note of the evening with
an instructive discourse whose object was to settle for all time the
controverted question as to which
actually is the butt-end of a billygoat. T-Iugh Dryden spoke on the
Hopkins of the future. "Eggie"
Gorman discussed several matters
connected with "Sporting Life,"
Harry Strauss dealt with his perilous progress from "common-sense
to Physics 2," ex-President Thompson spoke of his lamentable 'fall to
the position of sergeant-at-arms,
while Eugene Canton look for his
topic "The Woman and the Fat
Man."
Then came the time honored allusions to the immortal Geoffrey.
who dominated the remainder of
the evening in his accustomed glory.
The manner of introducing the subject of the famous pilgrimage was
handled with more than the usual
degree of originality and effectiveness. "Fred" Hall dealt with the
dusty road that wound its way to
the cathedral city; Manuel Gichner,
of freshman fame, gave an impassioned address on the subject of

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

PRES. WILSON TO ATTEND
INAUGURATION CEREMONIES
The President Accepts Invitation to Be
Present on Occasion of President
Goodnow's Inauguration Will
Make an Addrers.

It has been officially announced
that President Wilson will be pres.ent at the inauguration of President
Goodnow, which will be held at
Homewood in May. A delegation,
composed of Mr. R. Brent Keyser,
president of the Board of Trustees
Dr. Goodnow and Dr. William Bullock Clark, was most enthusiastically received at the White House
by President Wilson, and was given
the assurance that if nothing serious
happened to prevent him from coming to Baltimore, the President
would attend the. ceremonies ,with
great pleasure.
Upon being asked to deliver an
address at the inauguration, President Wilson not only accepted, but
added that he counted himself
greatly honored. He consented,
however, with the understanding
that in the event of an unexpected
turn of foreign affairs which would
demand his presence in Washington at the time of the inauguration,
he would be obliged to decline.
It is sincerely hoped that nothing
will happen to prevent the President from being present on this important occasion, and his coming is
being looked forward to with much
pleasure by all Hopkins men.
The occasion will have a double
significance, in that it is not only
to be the inauguration of Dr. Goodnow, but also the formal dedication
of the Homewood Estate. A large
number of invitations will be sent
out, and it is expected that the day
will mark the gathering of some
of the most prominent educators in
America. After the conclusion of
the exercises the doors of Gilman
Hall will be thrown open to visitors.
An optimist is a man who makes
lemonade out of the lemons that re
handed him.—Brawn Bninonian.
"Billy" Fulton set forth his views
concerning the much-frequented
shrine.
• The whole atmosphere of the
banquet was a peaceful one, no
terrified underclass men being present to lend a touch of eXcitement.
Only an occasional' burst of wrath
greeted a more than usually aged
or atrocious pun, and even these
uprisings proving brief and ineffectual, no Casualties we're reported
when the sophomores bid each other
fond good-night and went their
several ways.

BRICKLEY TO COME HERE SOON

DEBATERS TO MEET AT HOPKINS

New Hopkins Coach to Address Students
at Mass-meeting in Near Future.
Unable to Come Friday.

Teams From Virginia and North Carolina
Will Clash in McCoy Hall Final
Preparations Nearly Complete.

Afternoon and Evening Sessions
For catalogue apply to
EDWIN T. DICKERSON,Secretary, 301 St. Paul St

Charlie Brickley, the new coach
who is expected to do so much toward the development of strong
football teams to represent the University, was unable to visit Hopkins
on Friday and address the undergraduate body on the prospects for
the coming year, as he had hoped
to do.
It was found that Brickley would
be unable to reach this city before
an hour so• late as to preclude the
possibility of holding a mass-meeting
to hear him. He will also be
1
unable to come this Friday, being
prevented by a previous engagement, but there is every reason for
believing that his first visit will.be
made in the immediate future.
The new coach is •very anxious
for an .opportunity to address the
undergraduates• of • Hopkins, and to
arouse in the students a strong and
general interest in the problem of
developing.a winning gridiron combination for the coming season. He
further hopes that a .large number
of students in local •preparatory
schools who are interested in football and who are considering entering Hopkins next year will be present at the meeting, that they may
become familiar with the plans that
are being made here for the future.
of the sport.
Brickley will make a more official
visit late in the spring, when he will.
be .taken to. Homewood to see the
athletic field and will later confer
with the members of the Athletic
Council. Only a plan of campaign
for bettering the conditions connected with the development of a
winning team will be discussed, as
the terms on which the new coach
will come to the University have already been, decided and agreed
upon. The Harvard star will not
sign a contract until June, as he
wishes to remain an amateur during
th2 baseball. season, but full arrangements for his .presence here
next year have been satisfactorily
completed.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, MARCH 15, 1915.
BASEBALL TEAM TO LEAVE CAGE
Preliminary Indoor Work-outs Nearly at
an End--- Men to Go to Practice at
Homewood by March 16.

r-

The management of the baseball
team expects to have the candidates
Practice at Homewood the early
part of this week. The work-outs
in the cage have gotten the men into
condition for outdoor practice and
Coach Hooper is anxious to get his
squad to Homewood as soon as
possible. If the grounds are dry
enough the team will practice at
Homewood on March 16.
Coach Hooper is especially enthusiastic over the showing of his
pitching staff. They are fast
rounding into shape and by the time
the first game is played they should
be in mid-season form. Pythian
and Hollingsworth are two promising pitchers who have chances of
landing regular positions on the
'Varsity team. The outfield is also
showing up well. It is expected
that Pritchard, a new man, will
come out for the team this week and
materially strengthen this department.
Manager Short has opened negotiations with Mr. Beverly Ober,
manager of the Princeton alumni
team, and expects to be able to arrange a game with them. Ned
Harlan is the pitcher for the
Princeton alumni and will probably
show the 'Varsity some "big-league"
curves. Besides Harlan, the Tiger
alumni have several other star players and they will put a team on the
field that will make the Black and
Blue players do their best.
Assistant Manager France has
taken charge of the scrub team
schedule and is arranging games
with several of the best "prep"
school teams in the State. All the
candidates who do not make the first
team will probably have an opportunity to play in games for the
scrubs, and with the wealth of material out for the 'Varsity it seems
that a fast second team will be put
On the field.
LACROSSE SQUAD HOLDS FIRST
OUTDOOR PRACTICE OF SEASON

The lacrosse squad forsook their
old haunt last week and tasted a
little of real outdoor practice on
Wednesday afternoon, when nearly
thirty men went to Homewood to
open the outdoor season.
Much energy and spirit was exhibited by the squad, as they realized
that the steady fight for places on
the 'Varsity was making its real beginning for another season. Until
the weather becomes more settled the
first few practices will be held on the
old Country School field behind the
Carroll Mansion, so as not to injure
the Homewood grounds during the
early spring, when the soil is soft.
The squad has anxiously awaited
the time when practice could he
held in the open, as many of the
players have great difficulty in being able to see the ball in the cage.

LOCAL PEACE CONTEST TO BE
HELD IN McCOY HALL FRIDAY

The fifth annual contest of the
Intercollegiate Peace Association,
which is to be held in McCoy Hall
on March 19, and at which Mr.
Joseph Bartlett will represent Hopkins, is being looked forward to
with an unusual amount of interest
by all the colleges of both Maryland and the District of Columbia.
The winner of this contest will
represent the State and District in
the group contest of the South Atlantic States, in which Virginia,
West Virginia, North Carolina and
South Carolina will be the other
participants.
The winner of this contest will,
in turn, represent the entire group
in the final contest at Lake Mohonk,
where orators representing every
group in the country will be heard
and will contest for the muchcoveted prize.
The speakers at the State and
District contest are each required
to deliver an original oration of sixteen minutes' duration on some
phase of international peace.
The second prize of the final contest of 1913 was won by a Maryland man, Calvert Magruder, of St.
John's College, and, while the calibre of the participants in the coming contest at McCoy Hall is for the
most part unknown, there is every
reason to believe that Mr. Bartlett
may have an opportunity to acquit
himself as ably as a representative
of Maryland as he is expected to do
as a representative of Hopkins.

Membership in the Association of
American Professors has been extended to five teachers at the University of Washington. Invitations
were telegraphed recently to Professors F. M. Padelford, J. N.
Bowman, R. E. Moritz, H. G. Byers
and J. A. Smith. Only scholars of
acknowledged standing are admitted
to membership.
In addition to this, the men enjoy
greater liberty outdoors and do not
sustain the injuries resulting from
contact with the cinders and walls
of the cage.
The coaches are very well satisfied with the work done by the men
thus far. The squad is reported to
be unusually strong at this time,
with excellent prospects for a championship team.
There are two factors, however,
that have lately somewhat injured
the progress of the squad, namely,
sickness and the newly-organized
Independent swimming team. The
swimming team takes from the
squad such men as Primrose, D.
Woodward and Hoffman.
The lacrosse committee has not
as yet selected the successor to former Assistant Coach Julian Marshall, who left for London some
time ago, preparatory to joining the
British army. It is highly probable
that the matter will be entirely
dropped and no successor chosen,
owing to the advance made in the
lacrosse sason.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAR. 15, 1915.

Invitation.
Johns Hopkins has recently been
honored by President Wilson's acceptance of -the invitation to attend
the inauguration of President Goodnow, which was extended to him
by a delegation consisting of Dr.
Goodnow, President Keyser of the
Board of Trustees, and Dr. William
Bullock Clark. It is certainly with
no mean degree of anticipatory
pleasure that we note the fact that
Hopkins' most illustrious son is to
be present at this occasion, which
may be said to mark the beginning
of a new era in the history of Johns
Hopkins.
President Wilson has accepted
the invitation to attend with the
condition that he may be forced to
decline if matters of state demand
his attention at the time of the ceremonies in May. It is certainly to
be hoped that we may not be so
unfortpnate as to have to forego the
pleasure of having him with us on
this occasion. Johns Hopkins has
always taken great pride in President Wilson, and feels distinctly
honored, as well as greatly pleased,
that he is still interested in the
progress of the University to the
extent that he is willing to come
here, and to make an address at
the inauguration of our third president.
This occasion, which, besides being the official beginning of Dr.
Goodnow's term as president of the
University, will mark the formal
dedication of Homewood to the use
of Johns Hopkins, is being looked
forward to with much interest, and
the promised presence of President
Wilson serves to make the anticipaPresident Wilson Accepts

tion the more keen and impatient.
Let us rejoice in the beginning of
th:s new era at Johns Hopkins, and
in the fact that the exercises marking its actual inception promise to
take on such an added dignity as
that afforded by the presence of
the President of the United States.
The Sophomore Banquet.

The fact that a sophomore banquet
was actually held, and pronounced
by all who attended "a great
success," without a single freshman
"guest," brings to our attention how
well the new ideas as to the "education" of a freshman, which have
been adopted this year, are being
supported by the students as a
whole. For many years banquet
time has been the one certain occasion when trouble was sure to
occur between the two lower classes,
and a sophomore banquet without
at least a few freshmen to provide
sport would have been considered
a dismal failure. But last Thursday night found a sophomore class
actually congratulating itself that
not a single member had attempted
to follow the old tradition. This
unanimous stand the sophomores
have taken to firmly establish the
new traditions they are forming
under the new sentiment in regard
to hazing and class fights, is deserving of the heartiest congratulations.
• The, new system was much discussed at the banquet, and while it
may be said to be still in the experimental stage, some facts about
it were very clear to everyone.
First, that it has come to stay, and,
secondly, that the freshman rules.
no longer depending upon brute
force to enforce them, can be just
as effectively carried out by the
force of united effort on the part
of the three upper classes. Whereas, it was formerly the part of the
juniors and seniors to urge on the
freshmen against the sophomores,
the three upper classes must now
work together to make clear to the
freshman his proper attitude of respect and consideration to uPperclass men, and the meaning of
"Hopkins spirit." The sophomores
are resolved to continue putting
their theories into practice so that
Johns Hopkins may become a
worthy example to institutions still
struggling under the old method.
long believed to be the only practical one.
Dr. Remsen Receives Honorary Degree.

Dr. Ira Remsen attended the dedicatory exercises of the Mellon Research Laboratory of the University of Pittsburgh, February 26,
and the honorary degree of Doctor
of Laws was conferred upon him
by the University.
Revival of pan-American business, with increasing opportunity
for young men able to speak Spanish, is resulting in a growing interest in that language, says Professor Caroline Ober, of the University of Washington.

THE JOHNS

HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, MARCH 15, 1915.

The Henley Regatta.

AT OTHER COLLEGES
Michigan Research on Government.

A bureau of reference and research on government has been organized under the authority of the
Board of Regents of the University
of Michigan. The work will be in
charge of the Political Science Department. The purpose of this bureau is to collect information about
all subjects of interest to cities and
•to make this material available to
all cities in Michigan.
Students and members of the organization are at present collecting
charters, ordinances and reports of
various cities thronghout Michigan
and also treatises and important
documents of cities outside the
State.
*

*

*

New University at British Columbia.

Plans for the University of British Columbia have been completed
and the contract let for the science
building, the first of the series of
structures to be erected on the present site, which consists of 250 acres
at Port Gray, four miles from Vancouver, at the entrance of Burrard
Inlet.
The science building, which is
planned for the temporary accommodation of physics, chemistry, biology and certain other sciences,
but which will ultiniately be used
for chemistry exclusively, is expected to cost abouti$600,000. Additional expenditures of $2,000,000
are planned.
*

*

*

Yale Phi Beta Kappa to Raise Standard.

The Yale chapter of the Phi Beta
Kappa is taking steps to raise its
standard of admission, since the
present requirements are regarded
as too lax and are thought to be
an inadequate test of real scholarship.
*

*

*

Journalism Museum.

The University of Oregon has
started a journalism museum in
which will be preserved any object
of curiosity, human interest or educational value that is connected with
the business of printing and publishing.
*

*

American Academy Awards.

The American Academy in Rome
has just'issued its prospectus of the
forthcoming annual competitions of
the Academy for the prizes of
Rome in architecture, painting,
sculpture, landscape architecture,
classical studies. In the School of
Classical Studies fellowships will
be awarded of the value of $1,000
for one year and $1,000 a year for
two years. The fellowships will be
selected without examination other
than the submission of the required
papers. The jury includes, with
several others, Clifford H. Moore
and Chandler R. Post, both of Harvard University. Fellowships in
architecture, sculpture, painting and
landscape atchitecture, each of
$1,000 a year for three years, also
will be awarded.

The Henley Regatta, the world's
classic rowing event, will be discontinued in 1915 because of the war.
It will not be rowed until the cessation of hostilities. This is the announcement of the stewards and
something of the gravity of this
situation may be gained from the
fact that not since 1839, when the
first regatta was rowed on the historic course, have the stewards felt
obliged to abandon the races.
* * *
4,32a Foreign Students in America.

According to the report for the
year 1913 of the National Board
of Education, 4,222 foreign students.. were enrolled in the universities, colleges and technological
schools of the United States. This
number is larger than the total enrollment of either Yale, Princeton,
Minnesota, or Northwestern. One
thousand seven hundred of these
students were listed in undergraduate and graduate courses in arts
and sciences. The total number is
an increase of 577 over the enrollment of 1911.
The distribution of the students'
nationality was as follows: Canada,
653; China, 594; Japan, 336; Mexico, 223; Great Britain and Ireland,
212; Cuba, 209; India, 162; Finland, 124; Germany, 122; Brazil,
I 13; Argentina, 43. Every LatinAmerican country was represented,
except French Guiana.
This total foreign enrollment at
American universities does not compare badly with the foreign enrollment at German universities. 'Ake
foreign enrollment in Germany for
the winter term 1913-14 was 5,015
students.
* * *
English Collegians and Business.

At Cambridge University, England, an Appointments Board was
organized in 1899 for the purpose
of assisting graduates of the school
to find suitable positions as well as
to provide employers with properly
trained men. Mr. H. A. Roberts,
secretary of the Board, made a recent report in which he said that in
the period before 1870, only three
per cent, of university men went
into business. By 1900 the percentage had risen to twenty, and
at the present time Trinity reports
forty-three per cent, of its men going into business.
* * *
"Lost and Found" at Yale.

The Police Department at Yale
University has recently established
a lost-and-found bureau. The News
asks for the co-operation of the students in making the bureau a thoroughly efficient one.
* * *
Bowdoin Men Descendants of Alumni.

More than nine per cent. of the
students at Bowdoin are either the
sons or grandsons of Bowdoin graduates. In three cases, the students
have both fathers and grandfathers
who were Bowdoin men. The father of every member of the Class
of 1915 whose name appears in the
list of sons of Bowdoin graduates,
is a physician.

BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 15, 1915.

THE TIGER SWIMMERS WIN MEET

NOTED LECTURERS COMING HERE

SOPHOMORE BANQUET PEACEFUL

Defeat Hopkins Independents by Score
of 48 to 14 —Win Polo Game
Easily--Nourse Stars.

Dr. John Calvin Ferguson to Lecture on
Chinese Art —Mr. Harrington Emerson to Deliver Series on Efficiency.

Class of 1917 Holds Annual "Feed"
Without the Presence of Freshmen.
Hazing Done Away With.

The Independent swimming team
lost its second meet of the season
last Saturday night, when the
Princeton University squad came
out on top, 48 points to 14. In
the water polo game following the
meet the Tigers were again victorious, scoring six goals to none
for the Black and Blue. Princeton
has held the intercollegiate championship in this branch of sport for
the last five years, so it may be seen
that Hopkins did well to hold their
opponents to only six goals.
Although Hopkins failed to score
a first place, competition was keen
in all the events, the Orange and
Black tankmen having to work especially hard in the fancy diving
and 50-yards dash. In the former
event, -Hoffman, diving for the
Black and Blue, showed wonderful
form and was only beaten out for
first place by a fraction of point.
Frizzell, Princeton's captain, who
won this event, placed second in
last year's intercollegiates, and Berereton, who placed third, finished
in the same position in the championships. In the 50-yards dash,
Woodward and Rowland pushed
the Princeton men hard from start
to finish. In this event the judges
differed as to second place, as
Woodward and Madden finished in
almost a dead heat. The latter was
finally awarded second, with Woodward third. The other events in
which Hopkins showed to advantage were the plunge for distance
and 50-yard back stroke. In both
of these races the Black and Blue
placed second and third, Eiseman
and Getz scoring in the plunge,
while Woodward and Fulton placed
in the back stroke.
Princeton uncovered a varied and
wonderfully strong attack in the
water polo game. Five goals were.
scored in the first half before Hopkins became accustomed to the play
of their more experienced opponents. The second period, however,
showed a much stronger defense
for the Black and Blue, the Tiger
stars being held to one tally. Primrose, H. Woodward and Hoffman
starred for the locals, while Nourse
played althost the entire game for
the Tigers.
Saturday's meet will be the last
for the swimmers, three victories
haying been scored out of five
starts. Swarthmore, City College
and Marston's have been defeated,
while meets have been lost to Navy
and Princeton. Considering the
fact that this is the first year for
the sport at Hopkins, the Black and

Dr. John Calvin Ferguson, who
has for many years devoted his
time to the study of art in China,
will give an illustrated lecture on
"Chinese Art," Monday, March 22,
at 5 P. M., in McCoy Hall. Dr.
Ferguson was president of Nanking
University from 1888 to 1897, and
was president of Nanyang College,
Shanghai, from 1897 to 1902. He
has held many offices of importance
in China, and is a member of a
large number of honorary orders
and learned societies. His work in
China has been extended over many
years, during which time he has
played an important part in the development of many lines of governmental work. He has translated
several important works into the
Chinese tongue.
By virtue of his long and close
acquaintanceship with his subject,
as well as his powers as a lecturer,
his lecture next week promises to
be of an unusually interesting character, and should be especially well
attended.
Beginning with this evening at
8 P. M., Mr. Harrington Emerson,
president of the Emerson Company
of New York, will give a series of
lectures on "Personal and Industrial Efficiency," under the auspices
of the Department of Engineering.
The lectures, which are to be of a
non-technical character, will be open
to all members of the University,
and to the public. The topics are
as follows.
March t5—"The Great Stupidities."
March 22 — "Fundamentals of
Organization."
April I2—"Principles of Efficiency."
April 19—Modern Industry and
Efficiency."
Mr. Emerson, who is an efficiency
engineer of note, gained wide recognition on account of the results
he obtained in his investigation of
the Santa Fe Railroad system.
Since then he has held a position
of high rank among efficiency engineers and has done much to further
the application of the principles of
this rapidly developing science. His
subject is one which should appeal
to everyone, and in view of his
recognized greatness it, is centainly
a privilege of no mean worth to be
able to hear him.

One of the most interesting, original and thoroughly enjoyable banquets ever given by a Hopkins
undergraduate class took place last
Thursday night, when the Class of
1017 gathered about the jovial
board for an evening of feasting
and revelry.
The banquet was held at the
Hotel Rennert, and a large number
of hungry second-year men were on
hand when, at 7.30 o'clock hostilities were formally opened in a
private dining-room. Hopkins precedent was altered in the selection
of toast-master, in that Mr. Joseph
Chesley filled the position which is
customarily reserved for the class
president. Mr. Chesley acquitted
himself very creditably in the performance of his duties, and fully
justified the action of the committee
who requested him to do the honors of the evening.
As is by no means universally the
case, the speeches that followed the
banquet proper proved even more
attractive than had the delights of
French cooking, even though the
latter was disguised on the menu
cards arranged for the occasion
under highly suggestive and reminiscent titles. Eddie Stuart sounded
the - dominantly serious and contemplative note of the evening with
an instructive discourse whose object was to settle for all time the
controverted question as to which
actually is the butt-end of a billygoat. T-Iugh Dryden spoke on the

PRES. WILSON TO ATTEND
INAUGURATION CEREMONIES
The President Accepts Invitation to Be
Present on Occasion of President
Goodnow's Inauguration Will
Make an Addrers.

It has been officially announced
that President Wilson will be pres.ent at the inauguration of President
Goodnow, which will be held at
Homewood in May. A delegation,
composed of Mr. R. Brent Keyser,
president of the Board of Trustees
Dr. Goodnow and Dr. William Bullock Clark, was most enthusiastically received at the White House
by President Wilson, and was given
the assurance that if nothing serious
happened to prevent him from coming to Baltimore, the President
would attend the. ceremonies ,with
great pleasure.
Upon being asked to deliver an
address at the inauguration, President Wilson not only accepted, but
added that he counted himself
greatly honored. He consented,
however, with the understanding
that in the event of an unexpected
turn of foreign affairs which would
demand his presence in Washington at the time of the inauguration,
he would be obliged to decline.
It is sincerely hoped that nothing
will happen to prevent the President from being present on this important occasion, and his coming is
being looked forward to with much
pleasure by all Hopkins men.
The occasion will have a double
significance, in that it is not only
to be the inauguration of Dr. Goodnow, but also the formal dedication
of the Homewood Estate. A large
number of invitations will be sent
out, and it is expected that the day
will mark the gathering of some
of the most prominent educators in
America. After the conclusion of
the exercises the doors of Gilman
Hall will be thrown open to visitors.

Charlie Brickley, the new coach
who is expected to do so much toward the development of strong
football teams to represent the University, was unable to visit Hopkins
on Friday and address the undergraduate body on the prospects for
the coming year, as he had hoped
to do.
It was found that Brickley would
be unable to reach this city before
an hour so• late as to preclude the
possibility of holding a mass-meeting
to hear him. He will also be
1
unable to come this Friday, being
prevented by a previous engagement, but there is every reason for
believing that his first visit will.be
made in the immediate future.
The new coach is •very anxious
for an .opportunity to address the
undergraduates• of • Hopkins, and to
arouse in the students a strong and
general interest in the problem of
developing.a winning gridiron combination for the coming season. He
further hopes that a .large number
of students in local •preparatory
schools who are interested in football and who are considering entering Hopkins next year will be present at the meeting, that they may
become familiar with the plans that
are being made here for the future.
of the sport.
Brickley will make a more official
visit late in the spring, when he will.
be .taken to. Homewood to see the
athletic field and will later confer
with the members of the Athletic
Council. Only a plan of campaign
for bettering the conditions connected with the development of a
winning team will be discussed, as
the terms on which the new coach
will come to the University have already been, decided and agreed
upon. The Harvard star will not
sign a contract until June, as he
wishes to remain an amateur during
th2 baseball. season, but full arrangements for his .presence here
next year have been satisfactorily
completed.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, MARCH 15, 1915.
BASEBALL TEAM TO LEAVE CAGE
Preliminary Indoor Work-outs Nearly at
an End--- Men to Go to Practice at
Homewood by March 16.

r-

The management of the baseball
team expects to have the candidates
Practice at Homewood the early
part of this week. The work-outs
in the cage have gotten the men into
condition for outdoor practice and
Coach Hooper is anxious to get his
squad to Homewood as soon as
possible. If the grounds are dry
enough the team will practice at
Homewood on March 16.
Coach Hooper is especially enthusiastic over the showing of his
pitching staff. They are fast
rounding into shape and by the time
the first game is played they should
be in mid-season form. Pythian
and Hollingsworth are two promising pitchers who have chances of
landing regular positions on the
'Varsity team. The outfield is also
showing up well. It is expected
that Pritchard, a new man, will
come out for the team this week and
materially strengthen this department.
Manager Short has opened negotiations with Mr. Beverly Ober,
manager of the Princeton alumni
team, and expects to be able to arrange a game with them. Ned
Harlan is the pitcher for the
Princeton alumni and will probably
show the 'Varsity some "big-league"
curves. Besides Harlan, the Tiger
alumni have several other star players and they will put a team on the
field that will make the Black and
Blue players do their best.
Assistant Manager France has
taken charge of the scrub team
schedule and is arranging games
with several of the best "prep"
school teams in the State. All the
candidates who do not make the first
team will probably have an opportunity to play in games for the
scrubs, and with the wealth of material out for the 'Varsity it seems
that a fast second team will be put
On the field.
LACROSSE SQUAD HOLDS FIRST
OUTDOOR PRACTICE OF SEASON

The lacrosse squad forsook their
old haunt last week and tasted a
little of real outdoor practice on
Wednesday afternoon, when nearly
thirty men went to Homewood to
open the outdoor season.
Much energy and spirit was exhibited by the squad, as they realized
that the steady fight for places on
the 'Varsity was making its real beginning for another season. Until
the weather becomes more settled the
first few practices will be held on the
old Country School field behind the
Carroll Mansion, so as not to injure
the Homewood grounds during the
early spring, when the soil is soft.
The squad has anxiously awaited
the time when practice could he
held in the open, as many of the
players have great difficulty in being able to see the ball in the cage.

LOCAL PEACE CONTEST TO BE
HELD IN McCOY HALL FRIDAY

The fifth annual contest of the
Intercollegiate Peace Association,
which is to be held in McCoy Hall
on March 19, and at which Mr.
Joseph Bartlett will represent Hopkins, is being looked forward to
with an unusual amount of interest
by all the colleges of both Maryland and the District of Columbia.
The winner of this contest will
represent the State and District in
the group contest of the South Atlantic States, in which Virginia,
West Virginia, North Carolina and
South Carolina will be the other
participants.
The winner of this contest will,
in turn, represent the entire group
in the final contest at Lake Mohonk,
where orators representing every
group in the country will be heard
and will contest for the muchcoveted prize.
The speakers at the State and
District contest are each required
to deliver an original oration of sixteen minutes' duration on some
phase of international peace.
The second prize of the final contest of 1913 was won by a Maryland man, Calvert Magruder, of St.
John's College, and, while the calibre of the participants in the coming contest at McCoy Hall is for the
most part unknown, there is every
reason to believe that Mr. Bartlett
may have an opportunity to acquit
himself as ably as a representative
of Maryland as he is expected to do
as a representative of Hopkins.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAR. 15, 1915.

Invitation.
Johns Hopkins has recently been
honored by President Wilson's acceptance of -the invitation to attend
the inauguration of President Goodnow, which was extended to him
by a delegation consisting of Dr.
Goodnow, President Keyser of the
Board of Trustees, and Dr. William
Bullock Clark. It is certainly with
no mean degree of anticipatory
pleasure that we note the fact that
Hopkins' most illustrious son is to
be present at this occasion, which
may be said to mark the beginning
of a new era in the history of Johns
Hopkins.
President Wilson has accepted
the invitation to attend with the
condition that he may be forced to
decline if matters of state demand
his attention at the time of the ceremonies in May. It is certainly to
be hoped that we may not be so
unfortpnate as to have to forego the
pleasure of having him with us on
this occasion. Johns Hopkins has
always taken great pride in President Wilson, and feels distinctly
honored, as well as greatly pleased,
that he is still interested in the
progress of the University to the
extent that he is willing to come
here, and to make an address at
the inauguration of our third president.
This occasion, which, besides being the official beginning of Dr.
Goodnow's term as president of the
University, will mark the formal
dedication of Homewood to the use
of Johns Hopkins, is being looked
forward to with much interest, and
the promised presence of President
Wilson serves to make the anticipaPresident Wilson Accepts

tion the more keen and impatient.
Let us rejoice in the beginning of
th:s new era at Johns Hopkins, and
in the fact that the exercises marking its actual inception promise to
take on such an added dignity as
that afforded by the presence of
the President of the United States.
The Sophomore Banquet.

The fact that a sophomore banquet
was actually held, and pronounced
by all who attended "a great
success," without a single freshman
"guest," brings to our attention how
well the new ideas as to the "education" of a freshman, which have
been adopted this year, are being
supported by the students as a
whole. For many years banquet
time has been the one certain occasion when trouble was sure to
occur between the two lower classes,
and a sophomore banquet without
at least a few freshmen to provide
sport would have been considered
a dismal failure. But last Thursday night found a sophomore class
actually congratulating itself that
not a single member had attempted
to follow the old tradition. This
unanimous stand the sophomores
have taken to firmly establish the
new traditions they are forming
under the new sentiment in regard
to hazing and class fights, is deserving of the heartiest congratulations.
• The, new system was much discussed at the banquet, and while it
may be said to be still in the experimental stage, some facts about
it were very clear to everyone.
First, that it has come to stay, and,
secondly, that the freshman rules.
no longer depending upon brute
force to enforce them, can be just
as effectively carried out by the
force of united effort on the part
of the three upper classes. Whereas, it was formerly the part of the
juniors and seniors to urge on the
freshmen against the sophomores,
the three upper classes must now
work together to make clear to the
freshman his proper attitude of respect and consideration to uPperclass men, and the meaning of
"Hopkins spirit." The sophomores
are resolved to continue putting
their theories into practice so that
Johns Hopkins may become a
worthy example to institutions still
struggling under the old method.
long believed to be the only practical one.
Dr. Remsen Receives Honorary Degree.

Dr. Ira Remsen attended the dedicatory exercises of the Mellon Research Laboratory of the University of Pittsburgh, February 26,
and the honorary degree of Doctor
of Laws was conferred upon him
by the University.

THE JOHNS

HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, MARCH 15, 1915.

The Henley Regatta.

AT OTHER COLLEGES
Michigan Research on Government.

A bureau of reference and research on government has been organized under the authority of the
Board of Regents of the University
of Michigan. The work will be in
charge of the Political Science Department. The purpose of this bureau is to collect information about
all subjects of interest to cities and
•to make this material available to
all cities in Michigan.
Students and members of the organization are at present collecting
charters, ordinances and reports of
various cities thronghout Michigan
and also treatises and important
documents of cities outside the
State.
*

*

*

New University at British Columbia.

Plans for the University of British Columbia have been completed
and the contract let for the science
building, the first of the series of
structures to be erected on the present site, which consists of 250 acres
at Port Gray, four miles from Vancouver, at the entrance of Burrard
Inlet.
The science building, which is
planned for the temporary accommodation of physics, chemistry, biology and certain other sciences,
but which will ultiniately be used
for chemistry exclusively, is expected to cost abouti$600,000. Additional expenditures of $2,000,000
are planned.
*

*

*

Yale Phi Beta Kappa to Raise Standard.

The Yale chapter of the Phi Beta
Kappa is taking steps to raise its
standard of admission, since the
present requirements are regarded
as too lax and are thought to be
an inadequate test of real scholarship.
*

*

*

Journalism Museum.

The University of Oregon has
started a journalism museum in
which will be preserved any object
of curiosity, human interest or educational value that is connected with
the business of printing and publishing.
*

*

American Academy Awards.

The American Academy in Rome
has just'issued its prospectus of the
forthcoming annual competitions of
the Academy for the prizes of
Rome in architecture, painting,
sculpture, landscape architecture,
classical studies. In the School of
Classical Studies fellowships will
be awarded of the value of $1,000
for one year and $1,000 a year for
two years. The fellowships will be
selected without examination other
than the submission of the required
papers. The jury includes, with
several others, Clifford H. Moore
and Chandler R. Post, both of Harvard University. Fellowships in
architecture, sculpture, painting and
landscape atchitecture, each of
$1,000 a year for three years, also
will be awarded.

The Henley Regatta, the world's
classic rowing event, will be discontinued in 1915 because of the war.
It will not be rowed until the cessation of hostilities. This is the announcement of the stewards and
something of the gravity of this
situation may be gained from the
fact that not since 1839, when the
first regatta was rowed on the historic course, have the stewards felt
obliged to abandon the races.
* * *
4,32a Foreign Students in America.

According to the report for the
year 1913 of the National Board
of Education, 4,222 foreign students.. were enrolled in the universities, colleges and technological
schools of the United States. This
number is larger than the total enrollment of either Yale, Princeton,
Minnesota, or Northwestern. One
thousand seven hundred of these
students were listed in undergraduate and graduate courses in arts
and sciences. The total number is
an increase of 577 over the enrollment of 1911.
The distribution of the students'
nationality was as follows: Canada,
653; China, 594; Japan, 336; Mexico, 223; Great Britain and Ireland,
212; Cuba, 209; India, 162; Finland, 124; Germany, 122; Brazil,
I 13; Argentina, 43. Every LatinAmerican country was represented,
except French Guiana.
This total foreign enrollment at
American universities does not compare badly with the foreign enrollment at German universities. 'Ake
foreign enrollment in Germany for
the winter term 1913-14 was 5,015
students.
* * *
English Collegians and Business.

At Cambridge University, England, an Appointments Board was
organized in 1899 for the purpose
of assisting graduates of the school
to find suitable positions as well as
to provide employers with properly
trained men. Mr. H. A. Roberts,
secretary of the Board, made a recent report in which he said that in
the period before 1870, only three
per cent, of university men went
into business. By 1900 the percentage had risen to twenty, and
at the present time Trinity reports
forty-three per cent, of its men going into business.
* * *
"Lost and Found" at Yale.

The Police Department at Yale
University has recently established
a lost-and-found bureau. The News
asks for the co-operation of the students in making the bureau a thoroughly efficient one.
* * *
Bowdoin Men Descendants of Alumni.

More than nine per cent. of the
students at Bowdoin are either the
sons or grandsons of Bowdoin graduates. In three cases, the students
have both fathers and grandfathers
who were Bowdoin men. The father of every member of the Class
of 1915 whose name appears in the
list of sons of Bowdoin graduates,
is a physician.
